recommendedProducts.measures: Vitamin B6, B9, and B12 levels
recommendedProducts.title: B Vitamins
recommendedProducts.description: This at-home test is an easy way to evaluate your levels of three different B vitamins in your body. It can identify deficiencies and help you determine if dietary changes may be needed to improve your health and wellness.

internal.content: Vitamin B6 is commonly found in dairy products, fish, and meat. It keeps infections out of your body and helps red blood cells form (which carry oxygen through your body).  If you are not getting enough B6, you may experience things like rash and skin issues, mood changes, frequent infections, and certain neurologic problems.

Vitamin B9, or folate, is commonly found in green vegetables, fruits, and nuts. It’s crucial for creating your DNA (pretty important)! Like B6, it is also necessary for the normal formation of red blood cells which carry your oxygen. If you don’t get enough B9, it can cause things like mouth sores and fatigue.

Vitamin B12 is found in meat, chicken, and fish, and it’s common to have a deficiency, especially as you age. It is important for the proper function of your nerves – especially the ones involved with your vision. On top of helping to maintain healthy eyesight, low levels of B12 can lead to fatigue, weakness, and mood changes. To all of our vegan and vegetarian friends: B12 is not present in plant-based foods, so checking your levels can be extremely important—something you can easily do at home with this B12 blood test.

landingPageContent.title: When to get medical care for fatigue

content.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"It’s normal to occasionally experience some fatigue. If you stayed up late last night binge watching your favorite show, you might feel sluggish the next day. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"However, fatigue that doesn’t go away after 2 or more weeks can be a sign that something more serious is at play—so scheduling an appointment with your healthcare provider is a good idea [","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.mayoclinic.org/symptoms/fatigue/basics/when-to-see-doctor/sym-20050894?p=1"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"19","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"].","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

drinking alcohol and coffee (or having other stimulants, like nicotine) 4-6 hours before you go to bed","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Avoid eating heavy meals and spicy foods before bedtime","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Exercise during the day instead of just before place—and that it’s not too hot or too cold!","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Only go to asleep","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Try to get up at the same time every morning","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"unordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[],"nodeType":"hr"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Consider your sleep-wake cycle. (Melatonin exists naturally in your body as a hormone that helps promote sleep.)","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Melatonin supplements can be especially useful for resetting your body’s sleep “clock” if you experience jet lag or an irregular sleep cycle because of shift work. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Note:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" It’s always a good idea to talk to your healthcare provider about any supplements you’re taking or are considering taking—and remember that supplements do vary in quality, so be sure you’ve checked the source.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"How light affects sleep hormones:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" Your body’s melatonin levels are regulated by the amount of light your eyes see, so increased exposure to light later in the evening—including the light emitted by phones and computers—can make it harder to fall asleep at night and lead to tiredness during the day. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

If estradiol levels climb too high, you might experience bloating, breast tenderness, mood swings, headaches, weight gain, and sleep disturbance. Estradiol levels that remain chronically high can also increase the risk of serious conditions like breast or uterine cancer.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.metaDescription: Maybe you’ve noticed something…different…about your vaginal discharge. Perhaps there’s an unusual odor – or the color of the discharge isn’t the clear color that it normally is.

recommendedProducts.measures: Measures Chlamydia, Gonorrhea, Hepatitis C (HCV), Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV), Syphilis, and Trichomoniasis
recommendedProducts.title: STD Test - Female
recommendedProducts.description: Discreetly check for 6 sexually transmitted infections. If abnormal results are detected, you’ll have the opportunity to connect with our independent physician network and may receive treatment, if applicable.

internal.content: Chlamydia infections, caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis, are very common. It can be treated with antibiotics. Despite being easy to treat, the prevalence of chlamydia is high because most people with an infection have no symptoms and do not seek treatment, according to the CDC.

Syphilis is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. Syphilis is divided into stages (primary, secondary, latent, and tertiary). The number of primary and secondary syphilis cases—the most infectious stages of syphilis—is on the rise, with a greater than 9% increase in reported cases in men, and 34% in women in 2021.

HIV, or human immunodeficiency virus, is a virus spread via the exposure to bodily fluids, such as sexual intercourse or blood exposure. The virus attacks and impairs immune cells, causing progressive weakness of the immune system. HIV can progress to a condition called AIDS.

Caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, gonorrhea is a common sexually transmitted infection that can be treated with antibiotics. According to the CDC, many people with gonorrhea have no symptoms, which can lead to delays in seeking treatment and increases in transmission.

Hepatitis C is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis C virus (HCV), a blood-borne virus. HCV is more commonly transmitted through needles or blood exposure and is only rarely spread through sexual intercourse.

Trichomoniasis (or “trich”) is a very common infection caused by a microscopic protozoan parasite called Trichomonas vaginalis. Most people, about 70%, who have a trichomoniasis infection (about 70%) do not develop symptoms.

content.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"You may have heard that the gut is full of friendly bacteria. The vagina, it turns out, is also inhabited by a community of good, helpful bacteria – a community known as the vaginal microflora. Scientists believe that some types of vaginal bacteria actually protect the health of your reproductive system.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"These bacteria, it is thought, produce lactic acid – ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5045142/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"making the vagina a less hospitable place for germs","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". This, in turn, helps ward off infections of the reproductive system. However, despite this, infections can still occur.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Case in point: STDs.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Some STDs – though not all – can change the vagina’s microflora community by populating it with an army of hostile pathogens (“pathogen” simply refers to very tiny organisms, like bacteria or viruses, that cause disease). If that’s happened, then you might notice that your vagina’s discharges – which largely consist of vaginal bacteria – are a little different than usual. Maybe the color of the discharge is yellow or green. There could be an odd smell, too.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"So, if that’s what your discharges have been like lately, could it be because you’ve got an STD lurking in your vaginal microflora? Possibly, yes.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"But abnormal vaginal discharges aren’t only associated with STDs. In fact, there are quite a number of possible reasons why your discharge might seem unusual – in terms of its color, scent, texture, or volume. That being said, though, you can look for clues in your discharge – clues which hint at the possibility of an STD.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"So read on to discover what kind of changes STDs can cause in vaginal discharges.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Only some STDs are known to noticeably affect vaginal discharges. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2099568/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"There are 3 such STDs to be exact","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":": trichomoniasis (or “trich”), chlamydia, and gonorrhea.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Let’s consider each of these STDs in turn – and the effects they can have on vaginal discharges.\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Trichomoniasis and vaginal discharges","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"If you’ve recently been infected with trichomoniasis, then your discharge might be yellow-greenish in color – or, perhaps, just yellow. Additionally, you may experience a heavier discharge than normal – particularly as you near your period.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"This picture changes a bit if you’re experiencing a chronic, long-term trich infection – in which case, you might see mucus mixed in with your discharge.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

recommendedProducts.title: STD Test - Female
recommendedProducts.description: Discreetly check for 6 sexually transmitted infections. If abnormal results are detected, you’ll have the opportunity to connect with our independent physician network and may receive treatment, if applicable.

internal.content: Chlamydia infections, caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis, are very common. It can be treated with antibiotics. Despite being easy to treat, the prevalence of chlamydia is high because most people with an infection have no symptoms and do not seek treatment, according to the CDC.

Syphilis is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. Syphilis is divided into stages (primary, secondary, latent, and tertiary). The number of primary and secondary syphilis cases—the most infectious stages of syphilis—is on the rise, with a greater than 9% increase in reported cases in men, and 34% in women in 2021.

HIV, or human immunodeficiency virus, is a virus spread via the exposure to bodily fluids, such as sexual intercourse or blood exposure. The virus attacks and impairs immune cells, causing progressive weakness of the immune system. HIV can progress to a condition called AIDS.

Caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, gonorrhea is a common sexually transmitted infection that can be treated with antibiotics. According to the CDC, many people with gonorrhea have no symptoms, which can lead to delays in seeking treatment and increases in transmission.

Hepatitis C is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis C virus (HCV), a blood-borne virus. HCV is more commonly transmitted through needles or blood exposure and is only rarely spread through sexual intercourse.

Trichomoniasis (or “trich”) is a very common infection caused by a microscopic protozoan parasite called Trichomonas vaginalis. Most people, about 70%, who have a trichomoniasis infection (about 70%) do not develop symptoms.

recommendedProducts.title: Food Sensitivity (PKI)
recommendedProducts.description: This at-home test measures your body’s immune response to 96 foods to help provide guidance on what types of food may be the best to choose for an elimination diet.

internal.content: This test measures your immune system's IgG reactivity to foods, which can help guide a temporary elimination diet. This test does not test for food allergies. Food allergies are mediated by a different antibody called IgE.

landingPageContent.title: Health conditions related to joint pain

content.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Arthritis","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Arthritis is a general term that describes many different types of joint disease caused by joint inflammation [","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK518992/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"12","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"]. The most common form of arthritis, known as osteoarthritis, affects millions of Americans [","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/arthritis/basics/osteoarthritis.htm"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"13","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"]. Other forms of arthritis include rheumatoid arthritis (which commonly affects multiple joints at the same time [","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/arthritis/basics/rheumatoid-arthritis.html"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"14","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"]) and psoriatic arthritis (which develops in people with psoriasis, a skin condition).  ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Autoimmune disease","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Autoimmune diseases—like lupus—occur when your immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissues in the body, which can trigger chronic joint inflammation and pain. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Bursitis","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Bursae are tiny, fluid-filled sacs that help cushion your joints. Sometimes, these sacs become irritated or swollen. This condition is known as bursitis. Most cases are linked to repetitive motion, but injuries can also cause bursitis.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Tendinitis","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Your tendons are thick cords that attach your muscles to your bones. Tendinitis occurs when your tendons become inflamed. This inflammation is often caused by injury or overuse. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Fibromyalgia","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Fibromyalgia is a complex condition that can cause widespread joint pain [","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/fibromyalgia/symptoms-causes/syc-20354780"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"15","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"]. This pain may come with fatigue, memory problems, or mood changes. Symptoms of fibromyalgia often appear after an illness or injury. Researchers aren't sure what causes this condition, and there is currently no cure, but treatment can help you manage your symptoms.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Osteoporosis","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"As you age, you may experience bone loss. This condition is known as osteoporosis and typically affects women over age 50. But men and younger adults can develop osteoporosis, too.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"If you have osteoporosis, you are at a higher risk of fractures. Even minor injuries can result in a severely broken bone. Fortunately, osteoporosis treatment can help slow down or reverse bone loss.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

landingPageContent.title: Getting medical care for joint pain

content.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Many people experience some joint pain every now and then. But if you have chronic joint pain, see a healthcare provider for further care. Seek medical attention right away if you have joint pain after a sports injury, auto accident, or fall. Your pain might be a sign of a bone fracture or tendon rupture, which requires immediate care.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"When you see your provider for joint pain, they may perform a physical exam. They might also ask about your medical history. If you have a family history of arthritis or autoimmune disease, be sure to tell your healthcare provider. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In some cases, your healthcare provider may refer you to a specialist for further tests and treatment.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Your provider or specialist can help you create a personalized treatment plan. Your plan may include joint pain medication, surgery, or physical therapy.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

landingPageContent.title: Home remedies for joint pain relief

content.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Resting your joint may allow your body to heal and help swelling go down. You may also take pain relievers to reduce pain, swelling, and inflammation. Consult your healthcare provider before taking over-the-counter drugs.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Ice packs or heating pads may reduce your joint pain. Taking a warm bath, using a sauna, or getting a massage can also help. But these treatments may not be safe for everyone. Ask your healthcare provider for advice before applying ice or heat.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Maintaining a healthy weight also helps protect your joints. Regular exercise can be beneficial because it can help lower your weight and strengthen the muscles around your joints.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Testing for heavy metal exposure at home: ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Everlywell Heavy Metals Test measures 4 toxic chemicals that can put your health at risk—including cadmium, which can cause joint pain.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"value":"How is joint pain treated?","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Joint pain sometimes resolves on its own, and at-home care may relieve your pain. But if your symptoms persist, you might need to see a healthcare provider. Some people with joint pain might need to see a specialist for expert care.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Your treatment plan will depend on which condition is causing your pain. You might need to take medication or undergo physical therapy. Your provider can help you choose the treatment that's best for you.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[],"nodeType":"hr"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"value":"What causes joint pain?","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Many different health conditions can contribute to joint pain, including vitamin D deficiency and inflammation. Finding the cause isn’t always easy, but at-home lab tests—and talking with your healthcare provider—may help.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.metaDescription: If you find yourself wondering why you’re experiencing dry skin, read on to learn about common causes and simple remedies.

content.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Dry skin can appear seemingly out of nowhere and can be very irritating, especially when it is severe or extreme dry skin. Dryness can happen for many reasons, such as environmental changes, hormonal changes, medications, the natural loss of moisture that occurs with aging, and certain medical conditions—so keep reading to learn more about the causes of dry skin.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In many cases, lab testing can help uncover the reason for your dry skin. With Everlywell’s at-home lab tests, you can easily check thyroid hormones, levels of heavy metals—and more.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

landingPageContent.title: Seeking medical care for dry skin

content.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Many dry skin conditions are temporary and resolve with self-treatment methods, but if your dry skin persists, make sure to consult your healthcare provider. Your healthcare provider can help determine if there’s an underlying health problem triggering the dry skin—and create a treatment plan based on this information.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"A common symptom of thyroid dysfunction: ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In one study, dry skin was the most common skin-related symptom of hypothyroidism [","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3371544/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"9","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"], a condition in which the thyroid gland doesn’t make enough hormones. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Dryness can occur as tight, itchy skin or red, sensitive skin. Depending on your particular skin type, dryness may also cause flaky, rough skin. But regardless of your skin’s appearance or texture, here are some ways to minimize dryness:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"If you’ve identified a root cause, such as a new soap or detergent, make sure to first stop using the irritant and replace it with a milder agent, free of perfumes or dyes.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"unordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"You can also try adding more moisture to your external environment by using a cool-mist vaporizer or other humidifiers.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"unordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Use a thick, fragrance-free moisturizer as a regular part of your skin-care routine. Look for a moisturizer that’s oil-based, not water-based, as water-based formulations can enhance evaporation and irritate dry skin. Often, this type of moisturizer will be called an “emollient” or “cream” instead of a “lotion.” ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"unordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In cases of severe dry skin, you can even use petroleum jelly, which can be highly effective at trapping moisture into the skin.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"unordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In addition to a moisturizer, one of the easiest dry skin remedies is to simply increase your water intake. Try drinking an additional eight ounces of water with every meal or make sure that you are regularly consuming foods that have high natural water content, such as fruits and vegetables.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"unordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"value":"What is dry skin?","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Abnormal or excessive dry skin, known technically as xerosis cutis or xeroderma, refers to a loss of moisture in skin cells that form the top layer of skin (called the epidermis). Dryness can happen for many reasons, such as environmental changes, hormonal changes, medications, the natural loss of moisture that occurs with aging, and certain medical conditions.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[],"nodeType":"hr"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Why is my skin so dry?","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"To determine the cause of your dry skin, it may be helpful to examine your daily activities. For example, has there been a recent change in your environment or routine? Even a new workout regimen, such as swimming in a chlorinated pool, can be the culprit. Make sure to consider even subtle changes, such as using a different brand of skin care product, dishwashing soap, or laundry detergent. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Lab tests can also help find the cause—so consider trying an Everlywell at-home lab test that measures markers associated with dry skin.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}
